overview_of_class: Students in this course will investigate the early U.S. women's rights movement (colonial era through 1920) via the analysis of primary texts and the examination of critical essays. Students who complete the course successfully should expect to gain a complex and nuanced perspective on the rhetoric of early U.S. women activists, and also to improve their skills in critical reading and analysis.
name: Rhetoric of U.S. Women's Rights, Part I
title: SoC COMM_ST 324-1-20 Rhetoric of U.S. Women's Rights, Part I
enrl_requirement: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Sophomores, Juniors, and Seniors from every undergraduate school only.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Students in this course will investigate the early U.S. women's rights movement (colonial era through 1920) via the analysis of primary texts and the examination of critical essays. Students who complete the course successfully should expect to gain a complex and nuanced perspective on the rhetoric of early U.S. women activists, and also to improve their skills in critical reading and analysis.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Campbell, Karlyn Kohrs, comp. Man Cannot Speak for Her. Vol. 2, Key Texts of the Early Feminists. New York: Praeger, 1989.

subject: COMM_ST
